li.p: Let A=\begin{bmatrix} 1 & a\\ 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix} and B=\begin{bmatrix} 1 & b\\ 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix}. Compute the product A B. Based on this result, what is A^{-1}.

If A is a an m \times n matrix, we define the transpose of A to be the n \times m matrix whose rows are the columns of A. For example, the transpose of \left( \begin{array}{ccc} 1 &2 &3 \\ 4 &5 &6 \\ \end{array} \right) \textrm{ is } \left( \begin{array}{cc} 1 &4 \\ 2 &5 \\ 3 &6 \\ \end{array} \right). The notation A^t is used for the transpose of A.
If A is an m \times n matrix, are the products A A^t and A^t A defined? What are the orders of the products that are defined?
Given the following matrix, what useful information might you get from the products A A^t or A^t A.? A=\left( \begin{array}{ccccc} 16 &11 &4 &3 &15 \\ 16 &17 &13 &12 &6 \\ \end{array} \right)
Suppose that A, P, \textrm{ and } B are all m \times m matrices, m \geq 2, and A= P^{-1} B P. Prove that A^n == P^{-1} B^n P for all n \geq 1.
